Rabies cases on the rise in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai from the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office revealed on February 9th that in the past few months, rabies infection has increased in the northeastern region of Thailand, with a total of 74 people infected.
So far this year (from last October to September), 74 people have been diagnosed with rabies, 67 in Surin province and 7 in Buri Ram province.
All of them have been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
He also urged people to get vaccinated against rabies with their pets, and not to touch the saliva of animals that might be infected.
Rabies can be transmitted from dogs to humans, as well as cats and bats.
If a person is infected and develops symptoms, almost 100% die, but vaccination before symptoms develop can prevent death.

FUJI Preventing Accidents with Removal of Obstacles  System Development and Testing with Company Vehicles | Mid-Japan Economist, Economic Information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (headquarters: Chiryu City), which handles the installation of electronic parts and the manufacture and sale of robots and machine tools, has begun developing a system to prevent children from being left behind in cars, etc.
The system is equipped with a motion sensor in the car, which detects movement and sends a notification to the phone or chat.
Currently, they are conducting a trial in their own shuttle vehicles.
In order to prevent tragic accidents caused by leaving children behind, the company is working to ensure the safety of children.
Currently, two vehicles are being tested in the after-school English conversation school for children operated by the company in Chiryu, Teracoya THANK (Teracoya San-ku).
Three motion sensors, which detect movement by sensing the temperature difference between people and their surroundings, are installed in the ceiling of the car.
When the engine is turned off and the door is closed, if a person is detected after a certain period of time, an alert notification is automatically sent.
By linking the engine and door status and information, we try to prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The notification of the warning is sent through the cloud.
It can also be used to display the number in a computer or smartphone chat.
Multiple addresses can be registered to avoid mistakes such as missing a delivery.
The field test will continue until the end of February.
Kamiya Takeshi, chief of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department, said, "During the experiment, we were able to see other issues around the system."
For example, it has been able to pick up various issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment where drivers can concentrate on driving.
"We want to expand the solutions," he said.
The development of a system to prevent abandoned items on bus stops was triggered by a series of accidents involving abandoned items on bus stops across the country.
There was a proposal from an employee with children, asking if there was anything that could be done to ensure the safety of children.
We decided to develop it by utilizing the know-how we have cultivated through our FA (factory automation) related businesses, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, for information management.
Fujitsu's parking prevention system is easy to use.
The sensors can be installed simply by pinning them to the ceiling.
Because it can be easily attached to welcome vehicles, it aims to reduce the hurdles for adoption and promote widespread use.
Going forward, we are considering productization in cooperation with childcare facilities and kindergartens.

The ruins of the castle of Ukegahara, which was built in preparation for the battle with Hiraizumi Temple = Fukui Prefecture, Ono City, Ukegahara
It is located in the dry area of Ono City, Fukui Prefecture (Ikawa), where there used to be a large manor of Ukegawa.

It is said that the castle of Ukegahara was built in the central part of the Tokoyama mountain range in order to prepare for the battle with Hiraizumi Temple, which was in opposition to the shoen during the Kamakura period.
It appears in the military chronicle "Taiheiki".
There are no documents left about Ukegahara Castle, but in Taiheiki volume 11, "The suicide of the jito of Ukegahara by his own hand", the following is written.
Aiwa Ukyo Ryōkai (Aikawa Yukyo Ryōkai) was a retainer of the Kamakura shogunate. He was sent to Ono as a jitō.

In 1333, the Rokuhara Tandai, which was established by the court to monitor and control the western provinces, was defeated by Ashikaga Takauji, and the Kamakura shogunate was destroyed by Nitta Yoshisada.
When he heard the news that Rokuhara Tandai had been defeated, Suketoki Hara and his retainers fled, leaving only about 20 people behind.
The monks of Hiraizumi took advantage of this and attacked.
Time Treaty threw his wife and two children into the river, and then followed them, committing suicide.
=> Nobunaga, Hideyoshi, and Ieyasu, who all gathered to attack the impregnable castle.

A cat-shaped feeding robot is on display at the "Iwase Shio Aged Jingisukan Bon Ton Fukui Station Front Store".
Cute expressions and all that make it popular with families = Fukui, Fukui, Prefecture, Fukui, Chuo 2-chome
In Fukui Prefecture, where there is a shortage of workers in the food and beverage industry, there is a growing trend to introduce serving robots that deliver food to the table.

The robots are helping with the reduction of human resources in store operations and the "non-contact" customer service to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus, and their cute expressions are popular with families.
From restaurant owners and related parties, there are voices saying, "It will be difficult for local restaurants to secure employees and helpers, and delivery robots will spread even more."
"Jin, Jin, Djingis Khan♪"
The robot, which plays light music and displays a cat's face on its screen, smoothly serves food while moving around the store.
When it arrives at the table, it says, "I've brought your order, nyaa."
"Iwashio-nushi Jingisukan Bon Ta Fukui Ekimae Store" in Fukui City's Chuo 2-chome, one of the city's major restaurants, introduced a cat-shaped delivery robot in August 2022.

When a customer brings their order to a robot waiting near the kitchen, the robot picks up the order and presses the table number on the screen, then autonomously walks to the table to deliver the food.
AI (artificial intelligence) voice function and others are built in, and the cat face on the screen reacts when touched by customers, and has a variety of expressions.
The "Bonta Group" that manages the store has introduced the robot delivery service in two stores including this one.

President Saito Motohiro said the reason for introducing them was "because of the labor shortage," and emphasized that it was part of efforts to improve productivity through automation and digital transformation (DX).
The proportion of labor costs to sales is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21-22% by introducing robots.
The robots also collect used plates from customers, which is linked to the efficiency of the back-of-house, and "it's fun for families and kids, and it's good for promotion," he adds.
A barbecue and hot pot restaurant in Shinpo-cho, Araki, Fukui, called "Rokkan Hoshiyama Fukui-ten" also introduced a serving robot in August 2020.
Sonzan Shoten's Hoshino President said, "We couldn't find employees or part-timers, so we thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the labor shortage."
At the Fukui store, they divide the area where employees serve food and the area where robots deliver food.
The cost of leasing a robot is the same as the salary of one employee.
In an effort to cut costs, the store has also introduced a tablet-based ordering system, and is considering self-service.

According to the Fukui Prefectural Labor Bureau, in December 2022, the selection ratio for occupations such as "customer service" in the restaurant industry was 6.94 times, indicating a high shortage of workers.

The manager of a net system (Chuo 2-chome, Takami, Fukui) that sells meal delivery robots said, "The shortage of labor in Fukui's restaurants has become more serious due to the impact of the coronavirus, and there are many inquiries about introducing robots."
Hoshiyama president analyzed, "I think that it will be even more difficult to secure employees for local suburban stores in the future, and that delivery robots will spread."

Last year, they published an "okuyami handbook" that covers everything from necessary procedures and writing styles for when a family member dies to inheritance lists and family trees, and many people came to pick up their own copy.
In each area of the prefecture, seminars are held on how to write an obituary and how to prepare for death, and "end of life" has become firmly established among the citizens.
Echizen Town's Ending Note is 35 pages long.

It starts with a five-chapter review of one's life, and then goes on to record one's current health and assets, as well as one's wishes for future care, end-of-life medical care, and funeral and grave arrangements.
There is also a section for people to write down what they want to do in the rest of their lives, and a place to leave messages for loved ones.
There are 35 pages, but you don't have to fill out every page.
What do you want to write down for the people around you.
The most important thing is to clarify your goals.
There are many different types of notebooks available in bookstores and elsewhere, and you can start writing anywhere.
The term "retirement" was coined in 1909, when people started to think about their "end work."
In 2011, two years later, the Tohoku earthquake and tsunami occurred.
It is said that many people have come to face the reality that "death comes suddenly" and more people are preparing for their own end of life and end of life.
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic, which has spread around the world, is still not under control.
The prices have soared due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and this winter's electricity prices have reached unimaginable levels.
On the other hand, wages have not risen in line with the current high prices, and many people are worrying about the future.

On the other hand, once upon a time, funeral costs, care costs and the like, which could be shared with today's children, were divided among family and friends, but nowadays, it is becoming increasingly rare.
And the dilemma of longer lives is that the risk of dementia and the need for care increases as we age.
In the background of the transient nature of death and dying, we must remember the growing social anxiety.
Anyway, no one wants to overburden their partner or their children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular catchphrase, but it can't be left to individuals.
Rather than writing them down in secret, it's better to discuss them with your family and prepare calmly.

No mask required for children and teachers at graduation ceremony = February 10, Toda City, Saitama Prefecture
On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that children should not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.

"It's difficult to keep students apart from each other, and we're wondering how to deal with it. There are students who feel anxious about taking off their masks," said the principal of a large junior high school.
It is said that this topic is also being discussed among teachers after receiving news reports about mask use at graduation ceremonies.

On the other hand, the principal of one elementary school said, "If the government decides that they should not wear masks, then they will not wear them. It is not realistic to expect them to do so, except for singing."

In this graduation ceremony, some schools have allowed students who have been self-isolating to participate, and some have resumed the graduation choir, as they look for ways to ease the restrictions in some schools in the prefecture.
In the prefecture, prefectural high schools are planning to hold their graduation ceremonies in early March, while public elementary and junior high schools are planning to hold theirs in mid-March.

The prefectural board of education and city/town boards of education are considering how to respond after receiving official notification from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology.
There have also been cautious voices about the Ministry of Education's decision to not require masks for school education activities in general from the new semester this spring.

"Suddenly, children will be confused when they are told they don't have to wear masks anymore. It's natural that more children will take them off after being told they can," said the elementary school principal.

On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that from April, masks would no longer be required in school education activities in accordance with the new government guidelines.
Masks will not be required for singing, physical education, or club activities.

For the time being, until the end of the fiscal year 2022, we will ask for infection prevention measures in accordance with the current health management manual, and we will inform the education committees and schools of the details and points to note from April onwards.

At elementary, junior high, and high schools, as well as universities, graduation ceremonies in the 2022 academic year will be held with ventilation measures in place, and graduates, teachers, and students attending will be asked to not wear masks as a general rule.

NPO "Heart-touching Anthology & Editing Office" self-published the book "Dear Prime Minister, Your Breakwater of Life from Tōjinbō"
We have published our 10th book, "Dear Prime Minister, A Breakwater for Life: Tōjinbō"
All over the country, newspapers have been taking up the story, and many readers have sent in their comments.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the direct words of those who planned to commit suicide about the "social and structural" environment that is a cause of suicide in Japan, and to create a society where everyone can live with "a sense of purpose" by sharing this with everyone.

We have been patrolling the cliffs of Tōjinbō, a famous suicide spot in Fukui Prefecture, for 18 years and 10 months, in order to prevent suicide, and we continue to support activities to find and protect those who are planning to commit suicide and help them start over.

This book is a summary of the problems we have heard from the 784 people (2/6 currently) we have protected so far, and we are presenting the following 7 items to the Prime Minister as necessary measures to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there is a "human rights violation".
(3) Suicides are victims of organized crime in society.
(4)Administrative agencies are treating citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "outsiders" and treating them coldly.
(5) Mental health patients are being drugged and treated as accidents even if they commit suicide.
(6) The "duty of care" to high risk areas of suicide is being forgotten and commercialism is taking over.
(7) The teachings of new religious organizations are fraudulent, and their future curses and threats to extort money are intimidation.
The religious organizations that are committing these "fraud and extortion" crimes should be publicly excluded.

So, from the feedback we have received from those who have purchased this book, we have been sent comments such as "I was moved by the strong mentalities of those involved in this activity", "The former police officer in this book is a true police officer", "He is a bodhisattva who lives by helping others, even though he is not related to them", and we would like to share some of these comments with you.
I saw a photo in a newspaper and I was moved to tears thinking "what must they have been thinking..."
I hear that people are committing suicide because they are being pushed to the wall by the Corona crisis.
horrible, absolutely horrible.
Everyone is unique.
I hope it will be a society where I can live and enjoy my life with the life I have been given.
I have a great deal of respect and gratitude for the staff who have been working tirelessly for those who are suffering so much that they want to die.
I think this is a really tough job, both physically and mentally, and I hope you can take care of yourselves and continue to speak out in the future.
thank you.
kashiko
I hope that all of you, as readers, will become gatekeepers of life in your respective regions.

Toba City to double child-rearing allowances, demands refund - Ise Newspaper

[Toba] On the 10th, Toba City announced that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 12 households in the special allowance for child-rearing households (other than the household allowance) for the fiscal year 2020.
The city is apologizing to the affected individuals and asking them to take the necessary steps to return the money.
The city said it was discovered on January 27, 2020, when the guardians of the children who received the past payments pointed out the error.
When they confirmed the same year's total recipients, 79 households and 182 people, they found out that the payment made to 11 households on July 20th of Reiwa 3 was double-paid.
The city pays 50,000 yen per child under high school age in households exempt from residential tax.

The city had received data from the contracted accounting company that extracted the target children, but the responsible staff mistakenly thought that the high school students were included and added them to the data, resulting in double payments.
The city's childcare support room official said, "We will take strict measures, recheck the data, and do everything we can to prevent recurrence and regain trust."

On the 10th, Iwate Prefecture and Ichinoseki City announced that Belino Hotel Ichinoseki (Yamazato, Ichinoseki City) had been inappropriately using the subsidy for the accommodation fee subsidy program for tourists for about a year from October 2021.
When people who were not eligible for the discount stayed, the staff would apply the discount by lending them their names.
In addition to the unauthorized use, a number of cases were confirmed in which employees were using the hotel rooms.
The total amount of 7,231,000 yen, which was paid for inappropriate use, has been returned by the prefecture and the city, as well as the hotel's own investigation, by the 6th of this month.

The improper use of subsidies was in the prefectural accommodation discount "Iwate Tourism Support Project" and the city's emergency measures for tourist accommodation facilities "Ichinoseki Accommodation Support Subsidy".

The period was from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (October 30, 2022 for the Ichinoseki accommodation subsidy), and as a result of the investigation, 95 cases of inappropriate use of discounts for people outside the target area or unvaccinated people were found, totaling 5,870,000 yen, and

The prefecture's contractor was in the process of settling accounts when it was confirmed that the same person was both the user of the accommodation discount and the person in charge of accepting the hotel.

植物研究の先人紹介 早池峰山採集資料も 市総合文化財センター企画展【花巻】|Iwanichi Online 岩手日日新聞社

An exhibition that pays tribute to the pioneers who built the foundation of alpine plant research in Mount Hayachine, known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, and introduces the history of Mount Hayachine's alpine plant research, will be held at the Hanamaki City General Cultural Asset Center in Ohasama-cho until the 12th.

The exhibition collects 124 valuable specimens and materials collected by the predecessors, and introduces the footprints of the predecessors who were involved in the research of the plants of Mount Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian plant researcher Karl Johann Maximovitch (1827-91) at the end of the Edo period, and with Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), a native of Shiwa who collected plants under the guidance of Maximovitch.
Maximovitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country as a foreigner, asked Sukawa to collect plants and continued research for three years with bases in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

After Maximowitch returned to Russia, Nukawa continued to support his research, and the discovery of the endemic plants of Mount Hayachine, such as "Himekosazura", "Nambutouuchisou" and "Miyamayamabukishouma", were connected to this.

After that, modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cobanotsumecksa", "Draba japonica", and in 1905 (Meiji 38), "Arenaria katoana" that he discovered and named himself on Mount Hayachine.
From the exhibits, we can see that many researchers have discovered valuable alpine plants.

In addition, the article introduces the activities of Shimura Matsuzo (1874-1948), who conducted plant research while serving as principal of Hanaoka Elementary School and participated in the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-88), who was involved in the publication of "Plants of Oyama Peak

Yoshida Toshihide, a researcher at the Center, says, "There are many layers of research and connections between people behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine. We can show the connections between researchers from all over the country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter is about the belief and history of Mount Hayachine, the second chapter is about Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundation of Japanese geology, and the third chapter is about the features of Mount Hayachine from the perspective of geology.

[Gaziantep (Turkey, South) joint] According to the authorities of Turkey and neighboring Syria, the number of confirmed deaths in the earthquake that occurred in the southern part of Turkey exceeded 21,000 in both countries on the 9th.
The rescue of survivors from collapsed buildings and other structures is becoming increasingly difficult as time passes in the freezing cold.
Search and rescue efforts are underway in the disaster area.
On the 9th, the United Nations delivered relief supplies to the Syrian northwestern province of Idlib for the first time since the earthquake on the 6th, crossing the Turkish border.
Idlib province was the last bastion of anti-government rebels opposing Assad in Syria's civil war, and there were fears that international aid would not reach there.
Rescue efforts are ongoing in both countries, but are hampered by the difficult conditions.
Many are feared buried under the rubble, and the death toll is expected to rise.
Turkish authorities say they have confirmed 17,674 deaths in Turkey.
The disaster is the deadliest in Syria since more than 3,000 people were killed in a 1999 earthquake in northwestern Turkey that exceeded 17,000 fatalities.

Re-energizing and setting goals at Amami Airport, the second decarbonization promotion council meeting | Society & Economy | Naha Shimbun
The council meeting to discuss decarbonization of Amami Airport = Held on the 9th in Kasari-cho, Amami City

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Ando Toshio, Chief of the Construction Division of the Oshima Subprefecture Office of Kagoshima Prefecture, Council Members: 13), which was formed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Kasari-cho, Amami City), held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including online participants, attended the meeting.
They exchanged opinions on setting goals for decarbonization and introducing renewable energy, with solar power as the main focus.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from all airports by 46% or more from the previous year (2013) by 2040, in order to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.
In response to this, the council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to be the first among the other six airports in the prefecture to have a plan in place.
The second meeting was held in the same manner as the first meeting, with the exception of the opening, and was closed to the public.
After the meeting, Ando, the chairman, who responded to the interview, said that the meeting confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions of the airport.
The meeting was aimed at setting targets and introducing renewable energy, following the guidelines of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, he said.
According to the handout, the CO2 emissions from the airport's facilities and vehicles in the base year of 2013 were 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the emissions from lighting and air conditioning in the terminal building and other seven facilities amounted to 1,321 tons, accounting for about 90%, followed by aviation lighting (84 tons) and airport vehicles (71 tons).
The council discussed reducing emissions from these facilities and vehicles.
Ando said, "We are at a crossroads now. The direction of the committee members is the same, and we want to make sure we have a solid plan for the interim report."
Going forward, the third meeting will be for the intermediate report, the fourth meeting for the final report, and then they will draft a promotion plan.
"Kasama Real Estate" branch office opened to attract people to move to the island  Recruiting families to rent houses | Society & Economy | Naha Shimbun
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama real estate" = 8th, famous town

[Okinoerabu General Affairs Bureau] The opening event of the Okinoerabu branch of "sakasama-imu" (a real estate web service that visualizes the thoughts of people who want to rent out empty houses and shops), which took place on the 8th at the community space "entaku" in China-cho, Okinoerabu, aims to recruit landlords.
The company behind the service explained the concept during the talk session.

Okubo Masahiro, representative director of Tugino-ba (Hokkaido, Rishiri district), which operates the branch, said, "If we can get this project going on Okinoerabu Island, it will create a movement and a flow to attract people to the island."
Sakasama Immo is the opposite of the usual real estate process, whereby the information of those who want to rent is disclosed to the landlord and they negotiate and contract with each other.
On―Co Co., Ltd. (headquarters: Mie Prefecture), which operates it as a real-world experiment to discover vacant houses and build relationships through them, started the service in June 2020.
This is the seventh branch to be opened, and the first in Kyushu.
This is the first time in the country.
The event was attended by about 20 people, including On―Co staff and staff from the town office, the Wakkanai office, and two well-known towns, as well as local residents.

Okubo, the representative director, explained the background of the branch opening, saying, "I thought that if we could make use of vacant houses and shops while the movement to attract people from outside the island becomes more active, the town and the island would become more vibrant."

Persona songs are good!
I got to the ED of Persona 3.
I played up to 5.
I've completed Persona 4 on vita.
The things you can do are the same as in the previous Persona 4.
It feels shorter than the previous one because there's no story.
The music is still great!
Just listening to it makes me feel better!
The characters from Persona 3 were HD for the first time, so I was impressed when I first saw them.
Somehow, Junpei looks like an ikemen (lol), Persona 5 is already beautiful, so it's fresh...... If you think that way, then 3 is a better deal.
As for the music, I felt that it was easier to play than in 3.
Persona 3 has a lot of blue, but the backgrounds were too dark to see.
5 has bright colors like red and yellow, so it's easy to see even if it blends with the background.
It has a lot of assist functions, so I think even people who are bad at audio can play it.
For those who are good at music, it may become a game that is challenging to play with the challenge function turned on.
The triple pack includes Santa Rosa, but it's not just a bonus, it's a full 4-pack, so if you like Persona songs, I recommend this.
